item.title: The 9 best Glossier products that are actually worth it
item.description: Glossier leads the no-makeup makeup revolution. Over the years, we've tested several of its products, and you can find our thoughts on each of our favorites.
item.content:encoded:
When you buy through our links, Business Insider may earn an affiliate commission. Learn more

Glossier is leading the no-makeup makeup revolution with its easy-to-use products that don't cover you up. It's one of the best skincare brands, putting skin first and makeup second. And after launching in Sephora, you can test Glossier products yourself in more stores than ever.

Everything is intended to enhance your natural beauty, with cult classics like Boy Brow and Cloud Paint designed to give you a bare-faced glow. With a swipe here and a dab there, the sheer, buildable formulas create versatile looks that won't overcomplicate your routine. The skincare is just as impressive with its lightweight yet deeply hydrating Priming Moisturizer and Milky Jelly Cleanser, which is gentle enough for even the most sensitive skin.

Our team has tested several Glossier products over the years, and overall, we enjoy the simplistic nature and compatibility with different skin types. We've rounded up all of the most popular products and what you should know about each one below.

9 of the best Glossier products and what to know about each:

Glossier Futuredew

What it is: an oil serum hybrid

Key ingredients: jojoba, grape seed oil, evening primrose oil, rosehip oil, squalane

Suitable skin types: dry and normal

Benefits: enhancing, nourishing, moisturizing

Price: $24

Glossier Futuredew is an all-in-one serum, oil, and primer that gives skin a lasting dewiness.

The oil-serum hybrid has a slight pink tint that disappears into your skin as you blend the liquid, leaving behind only a glow — no glitter. Its jojoba, grape seed, and rosehip oils help leave behind a glassy, light-reflecting finish.

This illuminating primer is the very last step in your skincare routine, after any serums or SPF, and the first step before your makeup application. 

Despite the liquid being quite thick, it has a comfortable and lightweight feel. If you have an oily complexion, you may want to try it in moderation because this can add unwanted shine.

Read our full Glossier Futuredew review here.

Lash Slick

What it is: a film form (or tubing) mascara

Key ingredients: vegan biotin, natural shine polymers

Suitable skin types: all, including sensitive skin types

Benefits: conditioning, lengthening, smudge-resistant, water-resistant

Price: $16

Lash Slick's spiky bristles give your lashes a lifted, lengthened boost without the smears, smudges, or clumps. 

The hypoallergenic, dermatologist-tested, and ophthalmologist-tested formula is a match made in heaven for sensitive eyes and contact lens wearers. The mascara is also free of parabens, synthetic fragrance, and animal cruelty. 

One coat of the fiber formula makes lashes look longer and gives you a more bright-eyed look. Fibers wrap around the lashes but don't feel heavy like traditional waxy mascara formulas. It's water-resistant, not waterproof, so it won't budge throughout the day, but it also won't put up a fight when it comes time to remove your makeup. 

Read our full Lash Slick review here.

Cloud Paint

What it is: a versatile cheek color

Key ingredients: collagen, mica, pigments

Suitable skin type: all except some sensitive skin types

Benefits: easy to use, buildable, creamy

Price: $18

Cloud Paint is a liquid blush available in eight cheek-popping colors. No matter which color you choose, its sheer coverage lets you dab on a natural flush or build up to a bold monochrome look. 

Its power is in its versatility. You can use it as a cheek tint, a shadow, or a lip color. And as the name implies, it feels bouncy and light on the skin.

Cloud Paint generally works with all skin types, however, its mica ingredient may cause slight irritation to acne.

Read our full Cloud Paint review here.

Haloscope Highlighter

What it is: a dewy-effect highlighter

Key ingredients: crystals, coconut oil, castor seed oil, sweet almond oil

Suitable skin type: all, including sensitive skin types

Benefits: easy to use, enhancing, nourishing

Price: $22

Glossier's Haloscope Highlighter is a crystal-infused highlighter that'll help you find your inner light with three blendable shades: Topaz, Quartz, and Moonstone.

The stick highlighter offers both an inner and outer core. Its outer core, the "halo," is made with real crystal extracts that offer a natural shimmer rather than a glittery one. Its inner oil-based core has skin-conditioning and vitamin-rich ingredients. Use it to shine some light on your cheekbones or to brighten the inner corners of your eyes.

Haloscope is dermatologist-tested and formulated without fragrances, so any skin type can glide it on. Its coconut and castor seed oil with vitamin E creates a dewy sheen that looks beautiful no matter where you put it.

Lip Gloss

What it is: a cushiony lip gloss

Key ingredients: jojoba oil, vitamin E

Suitable skin type: all, including sensitive skin types

Benefits: non-sticky, nourishing, long-wearing

Price: $14

Glossier's Lip Gloss offers high shine without the stickiness. It's a comfortable, long-wearing formula with a reflective finish.

Available in clear, holographic, red, and a limited edition gold shade, the Lip Gloss is easy to wear for a high glam moment or an off-duty look. Just one swipe delivers instant, even shine that's locked in place. The formula has vitamin E and jojoba oil to keep lips soft and moisturized.

Boy Brow

What it is: brow gel pomade

Key ingredients: beeswax, carnauba wax, oleic acid, soluble collagen

Suitable skin type: all, including sensitive skin types

Benefits: thickens, shapes, and grooms brows into place

Price: $16

The Boy Brow is a pomade with a brushable, creamy wax that lifts and fluffs your brows. 

Choose from four natural tints or a clear gel, and then shape your brows with short, upward strokes. Its beeswax and carnauba wax hold your hairs in place without creating flakes or stiffness throughout the day. And, you don't need multiple coats to get it to sit right.

The brow tint formula is dermatologist-tested and made without fragrances or alcohol, making it suitable for all skin types.

Balm Dotcom

What it is: lip balm and skin salve

Key ingredients: beeswax, lanolin, castor seed oil, cupuacu fruit extract, rice bran and rosemary leaf extracts

Suitable skin type: all, including sensitive skin types

Benefits: soothing, conditioning, moisturizing

Price: $12

Glossier Balm Dotcom is a staple lip balm that nourishes intensely chapped skin. It comes in eight different versions, including four tinted options and fun flavors like Birthday and Coconut.

Packed with antioxidants and natural emollients, the universal skin salve has a dense texture that melts onto your skin. Its lanolin ingredient is a major bonus for sensitive skin, and thanks to its natural fragrances, you can have hydrated lips that smell good too.

Priming Moisturizer

What it is: a hydrating primer

Key ingredients: hyaluronic acid, mushroom extract, tea extract, honey extract, vitamins A, C, E, and radish root blend

Suitable skin type: all, including sensitive skin types

Benefits: soothing, buildable, noncomedogenic

Price: $22

Whether you're going bare-faced or you're about to apply makeup, Glossier's Priming Moisturizer is the hydrating lotion you need in your skincare collection.

The primer-moisturizer breathes life into stressed skin with a combination of hyaluronic acid, vitamins, and plant extracts, making your face feel like a smooth canvas.

A little of the light and creamy formula goes a long way, and it lets you build makeup on top without blocking your pores. 

Milky Jelly Cleanser

What it is: a gentle and creamy face wash

Key ingredients: rose water, comfrey root extract, Aquaxyl, pro-vitamin B5

Suitable skin type: all except some sensitive skin types

Benefits: soothing, purifying, noncomedogenic

Price: $9/2 fl oz or $18/6 fl oz

Glossier's Milky Jelly Cleanser feels as silky as it sounds. The pH-balanced daily cleanser uses five skin conditioners that work against irritated, taut skin.

Apply it on dry skin to remove makeup or on wet skin as an everyday cleanser. The rose water ingredient smells great and soothes skin while Aquaxyl creates a hydrating barrier to prevent dehydration.

item.title: Samsung S95D 4K TV review: The brightest OLED we've ever tested, but there's a catch
item.description: Samsung's S95D delivers exceptional picture quality. It's the only OLED TV with a matte screen that can nearly eliminate reflections.
item.content:encoded:
When you buy through our links, Business Insider may earn an affiliate commission. Learn more

The S95D is one of the best Samsung TVs you can buy and one of the most impressive high-end displays from any brand this year. It's Samsung's latest flagship OLED, improving upon last year's already excellent S95C. Most notably, it delivers the highest peak brightness I've ever recorded on an OLED display. 

It also offers top-notch color performance and incorporates a new anti-glare filter that cuts down reflections better than any display of this type. The matte screen does hurt black-level performance in bright rooms, but the S95D is the only OLED I've seen that can handle glare this well.

Competitors in this class, like the LG G4 and Sony A95L, perform a bit better in certain areas (and worse in others), but there's no doubt the Samsung S95D is a top contender in the premium TV market.

A new benchmark for OLED TV brightness

The Samsung S95D is a picture performance champ with all the bells and whistles that buyers should expect from a TV in this price range. Thanks to its QD-OLED panel (OLED with quantum dots), the display offers pixel-level contrast and a wide range of vibrant colors, which leads to exceptional high-dynamic-range (HDR) images. And on top of that, the S95D is the brightest OLED I've ever measured.

I put the TV in Filmmaker mode for testing purposes, which offers the most accurate picture settings. Using an X-Rite colorimeter, I measured a peak brightness of around 1,700 nits on a 10% HDR test pattern (a white box that takes up 10% of the screen). That's about 350 nits more than last year's version of this TV, the Samsung S95C, and about 200 nits more than the S95D's top competitors, including the LG G4. 

However, the S95D can only hit 1,700 nits in short bursts before dimming significantly. On the 10% test pattern, the TV gradually fell to around 750 nits and dropped more over time. I've seen this kind of behavior on a few other OLED TVs, but it's more extreme on this model than on competitors. But while that might sound like a major drawback, it actually isn't that big of a deal. It's rare for HDR videos to call for sustained brightness that high. Most highlights that actually need to get very bright (like a gunshot or an explosion in a movie) only flash on the screen quickly, and the S95D can handle those instances well.

As it stands, the S95D's brightness capabilities help the TV produce a vibrant image and give you plenty of headroom to pump up luminance and adjust settings to suit spaces that let in a lot of light. It also helps the TV display high-brightness HDR videos closer to how filmmakers intended them to look. And the results are fantastic.

The S95D delivers impressive image quality when watching actual movies and TV shows. During my testing session, I sampled various film sequences I use across all the TVs I evaluate, including scenes from 4K Blu-ray discs like "The Matrix," "Aquaman," "Ex Machina," "Blade Runner," "Game of Thrones," and "La La Land," as well as HDR streaming demos from YouTube.

With high-quality 4K material, the TV simply stuns. Fine details are sharp, contrast is high, and saturation is rich with bold hues that pop from the screen when called for. That said, while most demo material came through with the kind of bright saturation I expect from a QD-OLED with such high color volume, the climactic battle in "Aquaman" looked a bit more subdued than I was expecting. I have a hunch something wonky was going on with the settings, so I'll revisit that sequence when I conduct extended testing and update this section with additional findings. 

The opening scene from "The Matrix" is a great showcase for the S95D's contrast performance in a dark room. Bright specular highlights, like a police officer's flashlight, pop off the screen while black levels remain deep. And since each pixel on the TV's OLED panel can dim and brighten independently, the S95D is completely free from the kind of backlight blooming issues you'd see on competing QLED TVs. With the lights on, however, this scene reveals some of the drawbacks associated with the S95D's matte-screen finish (more on that in the next section).

The S95D handles gradients smoothly with minimal instances of banding. Our go-to real-world test scene from "Ex Machina" only revealed tiny hints of banding in the extreme red shades around one character's shoulder, which is about equal to what I've seen on other high-end sets.   

I also sampled a few regular HD videos in standard dynamic range and some lower-quality streams from Samsung's free live TV service, Samsung TV Plus, and the S95D handled them well. That said, upscaling isn't quite as good as you'll see on Sony's flagship TVs, so you'll get a slightly softer image with more source-related flaws visible.  

Note: The S95D is available in 55-, 65-, and 77-inch screen sizes, and they all offer the same display specifications. Samsung says all S95D models being shipped to retailers in the US right now use QD-OLED panels. However, there is speculation that the brand could sell versions of its 2024 OLED TVs with WRGB panels instead. WRGB OLED panels don't incorporate quantum dots, so any S95D TV with that panel type would offer reduced color and brightness capabilities. Again, this shouldn't be a concern for anyone shopping for an S95D now, but I'll update this review if WRGB variants end up being released in the US. 

The matte screen nearly eliminates reflections, but black levels suffer

One of the S95D's most striking features is its new glare-free screen filter. Virtually every other TV sold right now (including last year's S95C) uses a glossy finish that causes a reflective quality when you watch TV in a bright room. But, the S95D has a matte finish that significantly reduces glare and reflections. In fact, it almost eliminates them entirely. 

Seriously, this is one of the best screens I've seen for handling glare. The only other notable TV with a similar matte coating is Samsung's own Frame, but that model can't match the S95D's overall image quality. And when you add in the TV's high brightness capabilities, the S95D cements itself as a great option for rooms that let in a lot of light. However, the TV's glare-free screen does have a negative effect on black-level performance.

Instead of having the deep, inky quality that OLED black levels are known for, blacks look a bit elevated, hazy, and gray when watching TV with the lights on. This was very evident when viewing dark scenes, like the opening sequence of "The Matrix," in a bright room. 

I'm a bit torn about this side effect, and while I know that many buyers will love the perks of the S95D's matte screen, I lean toward preferring a glossier look that preserves black levels. I studied filmmaking and am a huge movie buff, so picture accuracy is one of the most important aspects of a TV to me. Deep black levels are a huge part of preserving the intended look of a movie, so the matte screen's negative impact on contrast is disappointing. That said, there's no denying how well the filter works at reducing reflections, so if you have a big issue with glare in your room, the pros here will outweigh the cons. 

Outside the matte screen, the S95D's design looks a lot like the 2023 S95C, and that's not a bad thing. This 2024 model carries over its predecessor's uniformly thin profile and has a similar pedestal stand, as well as a One Connect box, which houses all of the TV's video and audio ports instead of having them built into the panel. Build quality is also sturdy and a clear step up from cheaper designs used on sets from more budget-friendly brands. 

The smart TV interface is solid, and you can stream Xbox games with a subscription

Samsung's smart TV interface, which runs on the Tizen operating system, has received a few minor design tweaks for a slightly more streamlined look, but by and large, it offers a similar experience compared to last year's offering. 

Navigation through menus was snappy during my initial time with the TV and seemed a bit more consistent than last year's model. Some apps can still take a little longer to load than they do on dedicated streaming devices I've tested, but I like how there's now a loading bar that appears when opening apps. 

As with last year's model, the interface features a dedicated Gaming Hub section, and Samsung is still the only TV brand to offer built-in support for the Xbox app. This means you can stream Xbox games directly to the TV without a console, so long as you have an Xbox Game Pass Ultimate membership and a Bluetooth controller. 

Xbox streaming performance relies heavily on your internet connection and is limited to HD resolution in standard dynamic range with two-channel sound, but the feature gets the job done. It's not how I'd recommend playing top-tier releases, but it's solid for more casual titles.

Meanwhile, when playing video games via a connected console or PC, the S95D has all the premium features you should look for, including a variable refresh rate and support for up to 4K/144Hz to enable smooth gameplay.  

Should you buy it?

Based on my initial testing, the Samsung S95D is an excellent option for anyone who wants a high-end OLED TV. It delivers fantastic image quality with the highest peak brightness I've seen on a display of this type, and its matte-screen filter is a game changer for buyers who struggle with glare and reflections in their living rooms.

Celebrity beauty brands have been popping up left and right over the last few years, some to critical acclaim, like Fenty Skin, while others have left much to be desired. When Scarlett Johansson announced in June of 2022 that she was launching a skincare line, I wasn't just skeptical; I was confused. It's one thing for a celebrity known for their winged eyeliner or iconic red lips to collaborate with a brand or create a namesake label, like Gwen Stefani's GXVE Beauty. However, Scarlett Johansson's skincare label, The Outset, was one career move I didn't see coming, despite the fact the Marvel actor has an undeniably glowing complexion.

So, you can imagine my surprise when it proved to be one of the best skincare brands I've tried in my eight years of testing and reporting on all things beauty.

To create The Outset, the actress teamed up with former beauty and fashion executive Kate Foster to formulate clean skincare staples that do more for your skin with less (but better) ingredients. Its first collection included a cleanser, serum, moisturizer, vitamin C eye cream, and night cream that, when used together, create a complete regimen you can use day and night. After the success of the initial launch, The Outset has since launched an exfoliating micro polish, an ultra-lightweight botanical oil, and a blue clay mask.

I tested the brand's initial products for nearly a month and can say The Outset makes good on its claims that each item serves a purpose and that this skincare "works for you, not the other way around." Below, you can find my mini-reviews of each one, but overall, there wasn't one product I wasn't impressed by.

Gentle Micellar Antioxidant Cleanser

The Outset Gentle Micellar Antioxidant Cleanser was the first product I tried from Johansson's collection, and it set the tone for the entire line of products. It's a no-frills formula; there are no exfoliating beads and it doesn't turn to clouds of foam. It's made from a combination of the brand's patented botanical Hyaluroset Complex (a hyaluronic acid alternative), cleansing micelles, amino acids, and a blend of antioxidant-rich fruit extracts.

Above all else, I appreciate the simplicity of the formula. From its packaging to how it washes my skin, The Outset did a great job establishing itself as a clean label. Though it's worth noting the first time I used the cleanser, my skin was very irritated, and I did experience a slight tingling sensation. However, that has long since subsided and I've noticed my complexion getting softer.

Firming Vegan Collagen Prep Serum

If I had to choose a least favorite item out of The Outset's collection, it would be the Firming Vegan Collagen Prep Serum, but for no reason other than the fact that it applies sticky and leaves a lingering, tacky feel to the skin until fully absorbed. Quality-wise, it's an excellent product that performs as advertised; once absorbed, skin feels smooth and supple, creating the ideal blank canvas for additional products to nourish the skin.

Nourishing Squalane Daily Moisturizer

On a scale of 1 to 10, I'd rate The Outset's Nourishing Squalane Daily Moisturizer a solid 8. The formula is swarming with skin-nourishing ingredients, including the brand's signature Hyaluroset complex, hydrating squalane sourced from olives, and red rice extract to fight free radicals. In my experience, the product successfully softened my skin and, once fully absorbed, created a nice clean slate for makeup application.

However, I wouldn't recommend this moisturizer for very dry skin types. I didn't find it to be one of those thirst-quenching formulas, like Tatcha's Water Cream, that feels like an IV to the face. And because it does not contain SPF, you'll want to be sure to include that step in your daytime routine.

Smoothing Vitamin C Eye + Expression Lines Serum

Until now, I hadn't found an eye cream that worked for me. I have very dark under-eye circles and deeply set crow's feet in the corner of my left eye. I've used countless balms and creams, but nothing seemed to help before the Smoothing Vitamin C Eye + Expression Lines Serum.

I've been using The Outset's eye cream religiously (morning and night) for roughly three weeks now, and there's a visible difference in my eye area. This could be attributed to the formula's inclusion of Ascorbyl Glucoside, a form of vitamin C that brightens the skin. Still, it also could reflect the product's stellar hydrating properties and its inclusion of Irish moss. The cream also contains Centella Asiatica extract, which is rich in amino acids, beta-carotene, and other fatty acids that soothe and soften skin. Together, these ingredients work to plump, fill, and fortify skin.

Restorative Niacinamide Night Cream

While an optional step in your skincare routine (remember, you don't need a 12-step regimen to maintain a glowy, healthy complexion), I've really enjoyed tacking The Outset Restorative Niacinamide Night Cream onto my routine to give my skin a little extra love while I snooze. It's a rich yet lightweight cream that includes the brand's patented botanical Hyaluroset Complex, as well as niacinamide for brightening, bakuchiol for improving fine lines, evening primrose oil for extra hydration, and licorice extract to balance your skin tone. I notice my skin feels extra supple and smooth in the mornings after using it, but a rinse is necessary as I've found excess product stays on the skin.

item.title: We tested the viral TA3 swimsuits that double as waist-defining shapewear and were blown away
item.description: TA3's swimsuits use an adjustable construction that draws in your waist and provides more support at the chest — and it works like a charm.
item.content:encoded:
When you buy through our links, Business Insider may earn an affiliate commission. Learn more

Whether you're a Shark Tank lover or a TikTok scroller (or both), you may have heard of TA3 – a sculpting swimsuit company that didn't happen to receive a deal with any of the show's investors, but still blew up nonetheless. 

With 32.2 million amassed views on both TikTok hashtags #TA3 and #TA3Swim combined, it's safe to say that their swimsuit designs have garnered some serious buzz – and for good reason. The standout feature of TA3 suits is that they have a criss-cross corset back that instantly snatches the waist with a tug of the strings. 

The videos on social make it seem almost too good to be true, showing awe-struck reactions to the shaping effect. So, we had two people from our team take the suits for a spin, and see if the lofty price tag of $178 per bathing suit was actually worth it. Our experiences indicated that amidst the best swimsuits for women, TA3 may be the perfect suit to get you in the mindset of escaping the winter doldrums.

Before we dive into our TA3 swimsuit review, though, we'll just say this: All bodies are perfect just the way they are, and no one needs to change their body shape or make themselves look "snatched" in order to be beautiful. 

How TA3 swimsuits work

If you've yet to see some of the endless TikTok reviews on your FYP, here's what you need to know about TA3's viral one-pieces.

The fabric of the garment is described as a lightweight activewear compression material, not all that dissimilar to a super supportive sports bra. The front and back waist area is lined with a power mesh, and the high-quality fabric is meant to be supportive, smoothing, and never see-through when wet.

The corseted design starts at around the mid-back, near where the waist is typically smallest, and laces up to around the shoulder blades. With adjustable straps, removable bust pads, and some leeway with the corseted strings, the suit's sizing is quite accommodating and able to be modified depending on your preference for the day.

Sam's review of the TA3 Plungey swimsuit, size medium

You know that Photoshop feature where you can pull your waist in so that it looks smaller? Well, this suit does that in real life. Now, no one's waist ever needs to look smaller — all bodies are beautiful. But as someone with a larger chest and a short torso, I feel most comfortable in clothing with waist definition (A-line dresses are my go-to). 

And boy, oh boy, does the Plungey suit excel in waist-defining. It actually lifts your breasts while pulling your waist in, creating an hourglass shape that I've never seen with another swimsuit. I got tons of compliments when I wore this, which is a true testament to the power of this simple black bathing suit with its magic lacing. 

I'm five-foot-two, so I got the suit in the short version, but there are also different lengths, which is why this suit also made our list of the best swimsuits for long torsos. 

Sally's review of the TA3 Plungey swimsuit, size large

I opted for the regular plunge version of the suit in sapphire blue (there's also a high-cut version here). I have a DDD cup size so I specifically wanted to see if the low-cut suit could handle larger cup sizes. I was honestly amazed by how secure I felt while swimming and snorkeling during my vacation to Mexico! The suit kept everything in place and I felt really confident doing lots of activities in it.

I also love the way the pull-string emphasized my curves without making me feel too constricted. I could pull it tight for a compressive feel and more pronounced hourglass shape, but I could still let it out a bit when I wanted something looser. And, I really appreciate that the straps are adjustable and that I could opt for a short torso cut because I'm only 5'1. 

As far as longevity goes, the swimsuit has held up well for me even after washing it five or six times. I haven't experienced any discoloration or stretching yet. Given how sturdy the construction is, I suspect it's going to last me a really long time, making the $178 price tag more justifiable. 

Olivia's review of the TA3 Lacey swimsuit, size medium short

As someone who loves a more minimal, "always-in" bathing suit, I went with the roundneck Lacey style in a classic black hue. Thick to the touch and comfortably compressive, I immediately appreciated how easily this suit can be customized, with adjustable shoulder straps (that I quickly loosened for a more comfy fit), and of course, the corseted back that gives you some serious wiggle room when it comes to sizing.

I'm a medium in most articles of clothing, and this piece was very much true to size – and in opting for the shorter torso length, I found that it fit my 5'0 frame beautifully. Even without tightening the corset strings, I noticed some serious belly smoothing akin to shapewear that made me feel confident, accentuating an hourglass shape.

Personally, I do prefer more coverage, so I found that the bottom half of the suit was a bit tight and uncomfy, hitting quite low on the hips. However, if you prefer more cheeky coverage with a sexy twist, this may be the swimsuit for you. I also find bust pads finicky, creating unwanted lines and seams, so I appreciated that the ones this suit came from were easily removable.

Sally's review of the TA3 Lifty, F Cup

I love all of my TA3 swimsuits, but the Lifty suit is my favorite because the underwire is so supportive and prevents the dreaded uniboob that some one-piece bathing suits can cause. The way the sizing works is nothing short of a miracle. You get to choose your bodice length (short or regular/long), your usual swimsuit size (from XS-4X), and your cup size (from A-J/K,) to get the absolute perfect fit, plus there are a bunch of color options. I've truly never had a one-piece fit me better!

The thick shoulder straps are comfy and adjustable, and the cups cradle me perfectly with no digging. It even looks super cute as a bodysuit, so you could theoretically wear it with jeans or flowy linen pants and no one would be the wiser. But I know you're all here to find out whether it actually does what it promises to do, which is give you a snatched waist. The short answer is: yes! 

The longer answer is absolutely yes; the lacing in the back actually works like a dream to cinch your waist in. But the good news is that if you're ever feeling bloated or you just want something a little less compressive, you can always just loosen it up. It's like having two sizes in one! Anyway, if you have a large chest, you won't regret buying this suit — as someone with an F cup, it's definitely the most comfortable and supportive one-piece I've ever tried. This suit even topped our list of the best swimsuits for large busts because of the great sizing options and supportive underwire. 

There's even an option for a high-cut version of this suit here if you prefer to show more leg.

Sizing options and considerations

When shopping for your perfect size, note that you are able to choose from the regular/long or the short torso fit, which is available for all of their three current styles. And from XS to 4X, they have an impressive size range that feels inclusive and intentional. We found that the suits fit true-to-size, but the ace-up system offers a lot of wiggle room in terms of sizing. 

Different neckline styles can also be paired with different cuts on the hips, but not every style has a high-cut version. Personally, I would really love to see all of their styles available in both low and high cut legs, since I'd prefer the Lacey style with a more cheeky high cut instead as it makes my legs look much longer.

 

Other TA3 products 

TA3 doesn't just make swimsuits. They've also come out with a line of shaping clothing like dresses and bodysuits. These products are made for days when your destination is a bar or a dinner, rather than the pool or the beach. 

"I was obsessed with TA3's swim line, so I knew I had to try their regular clothing. Just like their swimsuits, the back of their bodysuits and dresses are laced like a corset to really cinch your waist in. I appreciate the structure immensely, but I think they need a little work to reduce bulkiness and increase comfort. 

"For example, there's a bodysuit under the dresses — complete with clever crotch gusset with a hook-and-eye closure for easy bathroom trips — in order to really hold you in. It works fantastically — but the lacing, the layers of fabric, and the thick material needed to create the cinching effect were a little bulky for me. The Scoopy Bodysuit is made from a soft Ponte fabric, but I found that the bulkiness prevented fitted jeans from buttoning. The Sqarey Dress, on the other hand, is made from a similar fabric to the swimsuits, which I found a little awkward. It's also a struggle to get into because of how tight it is. But there's no denying the cinching and smoothing effects of these pieces. 

"Overall, I found the clothing line to be highly effective and incredible shapewear, but you do have to be willing to pay the price of bulkiness, a getting ready process that requires you to really squeeze into something, and some discomfort throughout the day." — Samantha Crozier, style editor, Insider Reviews. 

The bottom line 

It's no secret that these are on the pricey side – but given the quality, TA3 is worth it. Each suit is an investment piece that will be a staple in your closet for many summer vacations of beachside getaways to come.

Aside from comfort and its customizable fit, many appreciate a piece that pairs well with an outfit in between sunbathing and swimming (say, walking around a beach town or at the resort lunch spot) – and this one-piece acts as the ideal complementary item for denim shorts, a swimsuit coverup, or even loose beachy pants.

If you want to feel polished, snatched, and totally secure when playing around in the water, this suit may be your next best purchase.

item.title: I tried Proven Skincare for 5 weeks and my fine lines are barely visible anymore
item.description: Proven Skincare's quiz and tested out the custom skincare products to see if it was worth the money. Here's an honest review of the process and products.
item.content:encoded:
When you buy through our links, Business Insider may earn an affiliate commission. Learn more

If you ever wanted to take the guesswork out of skincare buying and have someone hand you a list of the right products to buy for your skin type rather than having to piece together the right formulas on your own, then let me tell you about one of my new favorite skincare brands, Proven Skincare. 

Proven Skincare makes custom formulas based on a 3-minute survey you take about your skin. The brand originally debuted on Shark Tank in 2020, and though investors initially passed it on, my experience with the custom products convinced me they were mistaken. Using AI technology, Proven Skincare gathers personal skin concerns through a short quiz. Some of the questions you'll be asked include whether your skin is oily, dry, or combination, as well as your age and geographic location. The brand then formulates each product tailored to your specific needs. 

After you complete the survey, Proven Skincare will send you a kit that includes a cleanser, day moisturizer, and night cream. This takes the guesswork out of which ingredients in our products you should or should not mix and match. You can also opt for single products if you want to incorporate one of them into your routine rather than commit to the set.

The Proven Skincare team sent me a code to take the quiz and test its products for the purpose of this review. I've been using them for over 5 weeks and have seen serious improvements in the fine lines on my neck and the texture of my skin.

What the quiz covers

The process started with an in-depth quiz about my skin. Some examples of questions included if I was oily vs. dry, how my face feels after a shower, what my skin tone is (aka my melanin level), what age group I fall under, if I was breastfeeding, what my dietary habits look like; what types of products are in my current skincare routine; and, since where you live affects your skin, they also asked me to enter my ZIP code. Your answers are then used to create a personalized set with a cleanser, moisturizer, and night cream, all tailored to fit your skin type. 

My set included information cards that helped me understand how the results of my quiz translated to the ingredients in the products. For example, my cleanser contained the ingredient mandelic acid because it helps to reduce the appearance of sun damage since I spend a lot of time outdoors, a factor that I included in my quiz.

The company recommends you take the quiz every 5 to 7 weeks if you plan to reorder products so that it can take into account any changes your skin has experienced over time.

What my cleanser was like

The face cleanser was so powerful that it removed a full face of makeup (including mascara) without leaving any residue behind. What I loved most was that even though it thoroughly cleansed the dirt and makeup from my face, it didn't strip my skin or make it feel dry. When I received my products, the information card explained that the Proven Skincare cleanser was a face wash, toner, and exfoliator in one. The bottle is pretty small at 1.7 ounces, but two pumps (about a dime-sized amount) were enough to do the job.

What my daytime moisturizer was like

I am generally adamant about using sunscreen on my face every day, even having a generous amount of melanin, because I do a lot of outdoor activities like walks in the parks, jogging, and walking to the grocery store. The one-ounce moisturizer included mineral sunscreen (at SPF 30), which I really appreciated. 

Around three pumps of the moisturizer was enough to cover my whole face. Initially, the moisturizer looked like it would leave a slightly chalky layer on my brown skin, but it blended well once it was fully rubbed in.

What my night cream was like (with before and after photos)

The night cream was definitely my favorite product since it made my skin feel extremely hydrated and was the main factor in reducing the fine lines on my neck (not something I thought would happen, but it was a nice surprise). The 1-ounce night cream felt silky and rich in my hands, and when rubbed on my face, it left a hydrating finish that wasn't too heavy. Even after a full night of sleep, my skin still felt moisturized. 

The tranexamic acid, kojic acid, mulberry extract, and niacinamide in the night cream helped fight against signs of aging in my skin and firm it up in such a short period of time. Granactive retinoids in the formula also helped to smooth out the fine lines in my neck area. My skin feels significantly firmer and more hydrated than before I started using the product.

Cons to consider

Proven Skincare is definitely not cheap. At $145 for a cleanser, moisturizer, and night cream, you pay an average of about $50 per product. But if you can get over the price, the formulas really are worth it, in my opinion. The Proven Skincare formula wins out when comparing the cleanser to affordable skincare brands like Cetaphil, which are around $6 in convenience stores. Universal cleansers like Cetaphil just don't cater to all skin types, and I find they leave my skin dry afterward. I like Proven Skincare's specialized process aimed at addressing a multitude of my skin's specific needs — therefore, I think the benefits outweigh the price.

The bottom line

Overall, Proven Skincare helped me find a routine that worked and required little effort. 

The cleanser, SPF moisturizer, and night cream offer a three-pronged approach to skincare that I have been using religiously since receiving the set, but it's a nice benefit that you can just purchase a single product if you want. The quiz and resulting set of custom formulas allow for a uniquely personalized experience. After testing a set made for my specific skin concerns and needs, I would recommend Proven Skincare's kit to anyone who can reasonably afford it.

How to use an AeroPress

Each AeroPress comes with thorough instructions (also accessible online), so you're ready to launch into brewing as soon as you open the box. 

I brewed espresso-style coffee by boiling water and allowing it to cool to the temperature recommended by AeroPress, 175 degrees F. I then poured just enough water to moisten the medium-fine grounds into the brewing tube and let it sit for 30 seconds to allow the coffee to "bloom." (A technique used in the best French press, too.) 

After you add the ground coffee and water and stir to combine, you use the plunger to brew. I waited 30 seconds for the coffee to infuse the water. As you push down on the plunger, you add pressure to the interior of the brewing tube, which moves the water through the ground beans and extracts flavorful coffee in under 2 minutes.

A note on brewing: The AeroPress instructions call for a single scoop of coffee grounds per brew cycle. If you want a stronger brew, consider adding more coffee grounds to the brewing tube, stirring the water-coffee grounds mixture for 10-15 extra seconds, and/or using dark-roast coffee (or espresso beans).

Cleanup

The design of the AeroPress provides an easy cleanup process. I first unscrewed the filter basket from the brewing tube and used the plunger to push the filter and the coffee grounds into the trash can. The filter basket, brewing tube, plunger, coffee scoop, and stirring paddle are all machine-washable, so after a quick rinse, they went right into the dishwasher.

AeroPress espresso

Espresso-strength coffee is the signature brew style of the AeroPress. I wasn't surprised to discover that this device makes an espresso shot that's bold and complex, along with a long and nuanced finish. AeroPress espresso is equally appealing on its own or in the context of a latte; just add steamed milk, and you're in business.

For espresso, I poured until the water hit the "1" line on the brewing tube. The lower the number, the stronger the finished coffee.

AeroPress cold brew

Anyone who has ever attempted to make cold brew at home, DIY-style or with one of the best cold brew makers, can vouch for the fact that it is a long process. Turns out, the AeroPress works for cold brew, too.

To make cold brew with the AeroPress, replace hot water with room-temperature water. Pour the water to the "1" line on the brewing tube and finish brewing as normal. Then, add water and ice, and you'll end up with a glass of cold brew that boasts an attractive taste profile in a fraction of the time.

Possible cons

The small size and unique shape of the AeroPress means that traditional paper coffee filters can't be used for brewing, so you'll need to purchase AeroPress's own specialty versions. This isn't eco-friendly and can prove inconvenient (most retail stores don't carry these filters). The latter can be fixed by investing in an AeroPress Stainless Steel Filter, which is machine-washable and endlessly reusable.

Because the AeroPress comes in multiple pieces, it can be easy to misplace portions of the device. Fortunately, AeroPress sells a la carte replacement parts, so you can get a new filter basket or plunger or paddle.

What are your alternatives?

In terms of its flexibility and brewing speed, the AeroPress is peerless. That said, other single-serve coffee makers can replicate some of the AeroPress's most appealing characteristics. The Grosche Moka Pot also uses gravity and pressure to brew espresso-style coffee, and it's affordable and easy to use. However, it does require a stovetop and it can't make cold brew. Check out our guide to the best Moka pots to learn more.

Pour-over coffee makers achieve a flavor quality that's comparable to the AeroPress, although they take far longer to brew. The Kalita Wave Dripper 185 is one of the best pour-over coffee makers; it uses standard coffee filters, is dishwasher-safe, and has an intuitive brewing process. The Nguyen Coffee Supply Phin Filter is an even more portable option. The Vietnamese-inspired pour-over with stainless steel pieces that stack together and are easy to transport in the included pouch. 

The bottom line

After running a series of tests, I concluded that the AeroPress Original Coffee and Espresso Maker is one of the best ways to make coffee currently on the market. It's sturdy and light, so you can take it anywhere, and it's machine-washable. The AeroPress won our hearts with its affordable price and ability to brew a cup of coffee that a pro barista would be proud to serve in 2 minutes flat.

item.title: Café Affetto Automatic Espresso Machine review: The best option for beginners, but it won't impress the pros
item.description: The Café Affetto is as straightforward as brewing fresh espresso can be, but it lacks the adjustable settings that the pros look for. Here's how it works.
item.content:encoded:
When you buy through our links, Business Insider may earn an affiliate commission. Learn more

When making espresso at home, choosing the best espresso machine can be tricky, and serious espresso drinkers have a reputation for being particular. Many professional machines require other special equipment like espresso grinders and tampers to use properly. Easier-to-use automatic espresso machines don't often brew shots to satisfy experienced espresso drinkers — the ones that do can cost thousands of dollars, like our favorite, the Jura Z10. 

Balancing ease of use, cost, and quality of espresso is challenging, but we like GE's Café Affetto as a straightforward choice for under $600. With its built-in grinder and simplified brewing system, the Café Affetto provides an easy shot of espresso packed with flavor. We noticed some inconsistency in brewing and wish there were more manual controls, but we still recommend this machine for beginners. 

Design

The Café Affetto has a sleek, modern design that sets it apart from most classic-style espresso machines. The machine is available in white, black, or gray colorways, and each design has copper accents on both the brew head and the bottom of the drip tray.

All of the Affetto parts fit together snugly, and the machine feels sturdy and well-designed. The copper coffee spout is adjustable so that different sizes of the best espresso cups or mugs can fit beneath it. The machine is a little over a foot tall, similar to most coffee makers, but it has a length of 20 inches. Be sure to measure the depth of your counter before purchasing. 

Grinder and steam wand

The Café Affetto also has a built-in conical burr grinder with five different settings for coarseness. Brewing espresso usually requires one of the best coffee grinders, which can be expensive, so having a built-in grinder is a major bonus. 

If you want to make cappuccinos or lattes, you can get the Café Affetto with a built-in steam wand and milk pitcher for frothing milk. In our tests, the steam wand worked well for frothing milk but was limited in its range of motion. It moves only about 45 degrees from its vertical position which makes steaming the milk a bit awkward. On the plus side, the steam wand is removable for easy cleaning.

Brewing espresso

Brewing with the Café Affetto couldn't be easier. First, make sure the water tank and the bean hopper on the grinder are both full. Place your chosen glass or mug under the copper spout and then, using the touch menu, select between espresso, Americano, or "My Cup" to decide what type of drink you'd like the machine to brew. 

Once you push the button, the machine first rinses both the brew head and the steam wand. Then, it grinds the beans and automatically doses and tamps the grounds. The coffee then comes out of the copper spout directly into your cup without any input from the user. For espresso hobbyists, this is probably a negative, but it's a major plus for casual and busy espresso drinkers.

Cleaning

The exterior surfaces all wipe down easily with a damp towel, and the drip tray is removable for easy rinsing. Spent coffee grounds are stored in a plastic catch inside of the machine that you'll remove to dump out the grounds. The machine also gives notice on the control panel when the catch is full of spent grounds. 

There are some hard-to-reach areas inside the machine where coffee grounds can build up. To ensure your Café Affetto is properly cleaned, make sure to regularly get under the hood and wipe up any coffee residue or grounds that have accumulated inside the machine.

Cons to consider

Although the machine is very easy to use and performs as advertised, the ease of use means there aren't any manual controls. Brewing top-notch coffee with any method, using the best coffee maker or the best French press, is all about controlling the brewing variables — this machine gives the user very little control over the brewing process. The "My Cup" setting allows for some customization by connecting the Café Affetto to the local WiFi network and then, through a proprietary mobile phone app, adjusting the brew settings. In our testing, we found this process to be awkward and overly complicated.

Another issue we ran into was inconsistency. Sometimes shots of espresso would be watery and under-extracted. Without changing any of the settings, the next shot pulled would come out perfect. Without direct control of many of the variables, it's hard to know for sure what caused the differences between shots.

What are your alternatives?

If you're looking for something between the Cafe Affetto and a manual machine, the Breville Express Impress is a good place to start. It's a semi-automatic espresso machine that has 25 grind settings and a ThermoCoil heating system. You can pull a nearly perfect shot one-handed. Read more in our full Breville Express Impress review.

Of course, the quickest and easiest option is a pod machine, like the Nespresso CitiZ Original Espresso Machine. Original Nespresso machines use 19 bars of pressure to get the closest to espresso that a pod machine can. Find the rest of the best Nespresso machines in our guide.

The bottom line

The Café Affetto works as advertised — the built-in grinder and straightforward controls make brewing espresso as easy as pushing a button. Unfortunately, that ease of use comes with a bit of a trade-off. The machine doesn't allow for a lot of customization, and the brewed coffee can be inconsistent. If easy, straightforward brewing is what you want, this machine delivers, but other similarly-priced machines on the market have the ability to brew much better shots of espresso.

How much are Rolling Stones ticket prices?

Previous tours have seen artists such as Echo & the Bunnymen, Zac Brown Band, The Kooks, Cage the Elephant, and Ed Sheeran open for the rock band.

Will there be international tour dates?

The Rolling Stones have not confirmed an international leg for their 2024 concert series. So far, the only international show outside the United States will be in Vancouver, Canada, on July 5, and a one-off show in Germany on August 9.

While the tour is confined to North America for now, the Stones could announce an international expansion later.
